Dear Cody Akers:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM, and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Samatha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention Standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iii) Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or otherwise
suggesting physical or emotional harm to a youth.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Last night, during an AWOL episode (4/8/25), a security staff
member threatened a youth when they asked the youth if they
wanted to be thrown to the ground again.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Consultant learned of this information from Supervisor 1 during
an unannounced visit to the facility on 4/9/25.
Youth A was interviewed via phone on 5/2/25. Youth A reported
he and Youth B went AWOL on 4/8/25. Youth A reported Security
drove up in a vehicle and stopped near them. Youth A reported
Security threatened him and said something about putting him on
the ground. Youth A reported he couldn’t remember Security’s
exact words. Youth A reported he was really “pissed off” when
Security said this, and it made him even more angry and
frustrated than he already was. Youth A reported Supervisor 2 and
Staff 1 told Security to leave, so he did.
Youth B was interviewed via phone on 4/21/25. Youth B
reported he and Youth A went AWOL. Youth B reported Security
drove up to them and stopped the vehicle. Youth B reported
Security said something to Youth B about a situation that occurred
in the past with Youth A, but Youth B couldn’t remember what
Security said. Youth B reported Staff 1 yelled at Security to leave
and told him he shouldn’t have brought up anything about what
happened to Youth A in the past because it wasn’t any of his
business.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via phone on 4/18/25. Supervisor
2 reported she and Staff 1 were following Youth A and Youth B
because they went AWOL. Supervisor 2 reported Security was
present with her and Staff 1. Supervisor 2 reported she and Staff 1
stood in between Youth A, Youth B, and the vehicle Security was
sitting in because Youth A and Youth B were really angry at
Security (addressed in next rule section). Supervisor 2 reported
Security shut his vehicle door, but then reopened it and said,
2

“remember when you were slammed to the ground?”. Supervisor
2 reported Youth A and Youth B became even angrier. Supervisor
2 reported Youth A began banging on the vehicle windows and
yelled, “come on, let’s go, let’s fight”, while Youth B grabbed a
stick and hit the brake lights as well as the taillights. Supervisor 2
reported she told Security to leave, and he left.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 4/21/25. Staff 1 reported
Youth A and Youth B were upset and went AWOL. Staff 1
reported he and Supervisor 2 followed both youth, and then
Security arrived in his vehicle and stopped near them. Staff 1
reported Security said, “do you want to be thrown to the ground
again?” to Youth A. Staff 1 reported he and Supervisor 2 asked
Youth A to get away from the vehicle and shut the door. Youth B
broke out the headlights of Security’s vehicle with a giant stick.
Staff 1 reported Security was making other comments, but Staff 1
did not hear what he said. Staff 1 reported he told Security to put
up his windows and leave, which Security finally did.
Security was interviewed via phone on 4/29/25. Security
reported on 4/8/25, he received a text from facility staff (didn’t
know who) stating two youth from the facility went AWOL and
noted which direction they were headed in. Security reported he
saw two youth (doesn’t know their names) and pulled the vehicle
up near them. Security reported he never got out of the vehicle
during the incident. Security reported the two youth were violent
and hostile. Security remembered a couple weeks ago one of the
youth had contact with the police during an incident and the police
threw the youth on the ground because he was escalated.
Security reported the police had already been called for this
incident and were on their way. Security reported he didn’t want
the youth to have the same experience with the police this time,
so he was trying to warn the youth what could happen if the police
showed up and he was still violent and hostile. Security reported
he was trying to reason with the youth and explain possible
consequences if the youth’s behavior continued, which included
explaining the police might put the youth on the ground if he didn’t
calm down. Security was adamant he was not threatening the
youth. Security reported when the two staff (didn’t know their
names) told him to leave, he did.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Agency Response Strategy authored by Licensee
Designee dated 4/9/25 states Security will not respond to
any calls for assistance from the facility pending this
investigation.
3

• Incident Report (dated 4/9/25) for incident on 4/8/25
authored by Staff 1 states Youth A and Youth B went
AWOL and were walking with Staff 1 and Supervisor 2
walking behind them. Youth A pulled a street sign from the
ground and discussed breaking into Building B with Youth
B to watch porn on the computers, but Staff 1 advised
against it. Youth A tried to open the building windows but
then gave up and they all continued walking. Security
arrived and Youth A opened the door. Security made rude
comments about the last incident he had been involved in
and said, “do you want to be thrown on the ground again?”.
Staff 1 immediately redirected Security and got Youth A
away from the vehicle. Youth A and Youth B were upset at
Security and tried instigating Security to leave the van.
Youth B hit the van with a large stick and smashed a brake
light. Security drove off. Youth A and Youth B made
comments about how they would assault Security, and
Staff 1 redirected the comments, and reminded them the
comments Security made were not okay, so a complaint
would be filed.
• Written Statement authored by Security is consistent with
Security’s interview.
• Behavior Management Policy states staff will receive
Trauma Informed Environment Training and QBS Safety
Care Training annually.
• Standards for Staff-Client Relationships Policy states staff
have the obligation to be appropriate role models for youth.
Staff shall refrain from behaviors which reflect poorly on
themselves or the agency.
• Discipline Policy states verbal abuse including the use of
derogatory or discriminatory language, yelling, threats,
ridicule or humiliation are prohibited.
• Security does not have any disciplinary action in his
employee file. Security completed QBS Safety Care
Training on 4/3/24 and 4/5/24.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted,
there is not enough information to support Security threatened
Youth A. It is unclear what Security’s intention was in mentioning
Youth A getting slammed to the ground in the past, but there is not
4

enough information to support Security was making a direct threat
to slam Youth A to the ground in this situation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention Standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Last night, during an AWOL episode (4/8/25), a security staff
member called a youth a "bitch".
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Consultant learned this information from Supervisor 1 during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 4/9/25.
Youth A was interviewed via phone on 5/2/25. Youth A reported
he went AWOL with Youth B on 4/8/25. Youth A reported he was
frustrated and felt like doing whatever he wanted to do. Youth A
reported Security drove up and stopped the car, so Youth A went
up to the van and opened the driver’s side door. Youth A reported
he was trying to grab random stuff in the van. Youth A reported
Security yelled and cussed at him, but he can’t remember what
Security said. Youth A reported Security never grabbed or pushed
him and was only “talking shit to him”. Youth A reported they were
angry after Security cussed at him, so Youth B picked up a stick
and broke the taillight of the van. Youth A reported Staff 1 and
Supervisor 2 were both present and told Security to leave, so
Security left.
Youth B was interviewed via phone on 4/21/25. Youth B
reported he and Youth A went AWOL. While they were walking on
Pine Rest’s property, Security drove up behind them and followed
them. Youth B reported Security stopped the vehicle. Youth B
reported Youth A went to the car and began touching stuff inside
the car. Youth B reported Security was really angry at Youth A
and yelled, “Stop fucking touching me and my car”. Youth B
reported Security seemed like he was intentionally trying to make
Youth A upset by the way he was yelling at him. Youth B reported
he was upset by what Security did, so he picked up a stick and hit
the vehicle. Youth B reported Youth A was “pissed off” but couldn’t
5

do anything because Staff 1 and Supervisor 2 were blocking him
from getting to the van. Youth B reported Staff 1 and Supervisor 2
told Security to leave, so Security left.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via phone on 4/18/25. Supervisor
2 reported she and Staff 1 were following Youth A and Youth B
because they went AWOL. Supervisor 2 reported she texted
Security to update him on their location. Supervisor 2 reported
Security drove his vehicle up and stopped in front of them.
Supervisor 2 reported Youth A went to the vehicle, grabbed the
handle to the driver’s side door, opened it, and honked the
vehicle’s horn. Supervisor 2 reported Security said, “don’t fucking
touch that bitch” to Youth A. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A and
Youth B became upset, so Supervisor 2 and Staff 1 separated
them from the vehicle because they both wanted to fight Security.
Supervisor 2 reported Security never got out of his vehicle, and
after Supervisor 2 and Staff 1 told Security to leave, he left.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 4/21/25. Staff 1 reported
when Security arrived and stopped his vehicle near them, Youth A
opened the driver’s side door and tried to grab the steering wheel.
Staff 1 reported Security yelled, “bitch!” to Youth A and got Youth
A off the steering wheel somehow. Staff 1 reported he saw
Security sometime after the incident, and Security apologized and
admitted he freaked out. Staff 1 reported Security seemed to know
what he did was wrong, but Staff 1 reiterated Security’s reaction
during the situation was completely inappropriate.
Security was interviewed via phone on 4/29/25. Security
reported on 4/8/25, he received a text from facility staff (didn’t
know who) stating two youth from the facility went AWOL and
noted which direction they were headed in. Security reported he
saw two youth (doesn’t know their names) and pulled the vehicle
up near them. Security reported his foot was still on the brake, and
he hadn’t officially parked the car. Security reported one youth
opened the driver’s side door and began poking at settings,
pushing buttons, and grabbing the steering wheel. Security
reported as a knee jerk reaction, he pushed the youth’s hand off
the steering wheel and cussed at him. Security reported he can’t
remember what he said, but admitted it was unprofessional and
was something to the extent of, “get your fucking hands off the
wheel”. Security reported the words just slipped out, and he’s
never lost his cool before, so he feels really bad about it. Security
reported when he has assisted in incidents previously, normally
he's on “equal footing” (such as standing in a wide open facility
and having space), but this time he was in his vehicle, and he was
6

caught off guard. Security reported he was later told he called the
youth a “bitch”, but he doesn’t remember saying it. Security
reported he’s never lost his cool during any other escalated
situations. Security reported he still feels bad about what
happened, and he apologized to his supervisor about it. Security
reported he is willing to apologize to the youth as well. Security
reported he is unaware of the programming the facility provides or
the histories of the youth at the facility. Security reported for the
first 6-8 months of working at Pine Rest, he never received a call
from the facility, and it’s only been the last 3-4 months he has
received calls requesting assistance. Security reported he was
trained in QBS and de-escalation training and is due for a
refresher in May 2025.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Agency Response Strategy authored by Licensee
Designee dated 4/9/25 states Security will not respond to
any calls for assistance from the facility pending this
investigation.
• Incident Report (dated 4/9/25) for incident on 4/8/25
authored by Staff 1 states Security said, “don’t touch the
steering wheel bitch” to Youth A when Youth A grabbed the
steering wheel of the vehicle.
• Written Statement authored by Security is consistent with
Security’s interview.
• Behavior Management Policy states staff will receive
Trauma Informed Environment Training and QBS Safety
Care Training annually.
• Standards for Staff-Client Relationships Policy states staff
have the obligation to be appropriate role models for youth.
Staff shall refrain from behaviors which reflect poorly on
themselves or the agency.
• Discipline Policy states verbal abuse including the use of
derogatory or discriminatory language, yelling, threats,
ridicule or humiliation are prohibited.
• Security does not have any disciplinary action in his
employee file. Security completed QBS Safety Care
Training on 4/3/24 and 4/5/24.
7

Analysis The facility is found in violation as per interviews conducted,
Security called Youth A, a profane name and used profanity when
speaking to Youth A.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility should ensure all non-Maple Lodge specific staff who
report for incidents and/or have contact with the facility’s youth
have an overview of the facility’s programming prior to assisting
with the facility’s youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR #2025SIC0000502 dated 4/17/25; CAP approved 5/5/25
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff 1 did not complete training per the facility’s policies.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Security was interviewed via phone on 4/29/25. Security
reported he was trained in QBS and de-escalation training last
year and is due for a refresher in May 2025.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Behavior Management Policy states staff will receive
Trauma Informed Environment Training and QBS Safety
Care Training annually.
• QBS Training Requirements Policy states all staff must be
re-certified annually on or before the date of the previous
date taken. If certification expires, a corrective action will be
administered, and staff will be required to complete training
and be recertified within 90 days of certification expiring.
• Email from Licensee Designee dated 5/21/25 states
security staff “were not previously required to take trauma
informed care training. Security staff will be taking it going
forward. [The facility] is working to get them scheduled and
hope to have training complete by July 1”.
• Security does not have any disciplinary action in his
employee file. Security completed QBS Safety Care
8

Training on 4/3/24 and 4/5/24. There is no record of
Security completing QBS safety care annually on or before
the previous date taken. There is no record of Security
completing Trauma Informed Environment Training.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as per the interview conducted and
documentation reviewed, Security did not complete Trauma
Informed Environment Training as required by the facility’s
Behavior Management Policy and did not complete a QBS Safety
refresher annually on or before the previous date taken as
required by the facility’s QBS Training Requirements Policy. In
addition, Security’s employee file did not show corrective action
was taken as a result of his expired certification.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility should ensure all non-Maple Lodge specific staff who
report to incidents and/or have contact with the facility’s youth
complete Trauma Informed Environment Training as required by
the Facility’s Behavior Management Policy as well as any other
trainings listed in various other Maple Lodge policies.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
